results.title: Two Laws
results.brief_description: An innovative film on the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of First Nations law. First Nations people actively collaborated with the filmmakers in determining the form of the film which is in four parts. “Police times” is a dramatic re-enactment of white oppression in the 1930’s. “Welfare times” A re-enactment of life under the welfare system of the 1950’s. In “Struggle for our land” First Nations peoples’ attachment to the land is described and the first hearing of the Borroloola land claim is also re-enacted. “Living with two laws” is concerned with the movement back to traditional land and the setting up of cattle out-stations.

results.title: Buildings and Bushfires-Improving the Chances of Survival
results.creator_credit: University of Melbourne and Television Production Unit
results.brief_description: Bushfires are an inevitable hazard in Australia. The tranquillity of the bush belies its potential to burn fiercely when conditions are suitable. This program shows how bushfires start fires in buildings, how embers, radiation and flame, aided by wind cause ignition and destruction of buildings; that embers are the most important means of ignition; that well-designed buildings have a very good chance of survival; and that such buildings will provide a safer place of refuge for people in bushfires.
results.title_for_label: Buildings and Bushfires-Improving the Chances of Survival

results.title: Heaven help us!
results.creator_credit: Robert Kingsbury, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: There’s only one thing wrong with telephones: people use them. This film sets out to explain the simple rules of telephone etiquette with special effects and fantasy sequences. Max Meldrum plays an angel, who for some reason is in charge of heaven’s communications systems! Using a shonky business as an example, he explains the do’s and dont’s of good communication over the phone. Produced for the Australian Post Office.

results.title: Media Education (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Children must learn to evaluate and understand the language of media forms. By actively participating in media studies classes, film making, role playing and newscasting, they learn to question what they see and read, and become more aware of good and bad production

results.title: Lousy Little Sixpence
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Gerald Bostock and Sixpence Productions
results.brief_description: Archival film footage, photographs and the memories of Aboriginal elders weave a moving account of the lives of Aboriginal people and their struggle in the 1930s against the Aborigines Protection Board.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Alec Morgan, Gerald Bostock and Sixpence Productions
results.description: A landmark Australian documentary focusing on Australia’s Stolen Generations, the government policies of forced removal of children from First Nations communities that created them, and the resistance of First Nations people to the theft of their families, lands and cultures.
description_for_label: A landmark Australian documentary focusing on Australia’s Stolen Generations, the government policies of forced removal of children from First Nations communities that created them, and the resistance of First Nations people to the theft of their families, lands and cultures.

results.title: Country Outcasts
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
Country outcasts is a small pop band made up from a number of talented First Nations people who have spent their lives in a wholly urbanised environment. This film is the story of a tour that this band makes through the outback, and the thoughts and feelings that are aroused within these city dwellers when they meet other First Nations peoples in Central Australia.

results.title: Summer school in Singapore
results.brief_description: As part of the Colombo Plan thirty-five students from Cambodia and Laos were invited by the United Kingdom Government to attend a summer-school in Singapore for a six-week course in the English language. The school was held in the University of Malaya and the students came from varied walks of life - government officials, teachers and high-school students. Emphasis was laid on conversational English, its rhythm, pronunciation and vocabulary.

results.title: Soils of Australia
results.creator_credit: D.G. Corke, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Explains the classification and mapping of Australian soils, and discusses structure, nutrient status and current use of twelve soil groups in relation to their climatic zones.

results.title: Sheep on show
results.brief_description: A special sheep show was held in Melbourne at the time of the Olympic Games, and to further publicise the wool industry a large party of foreign journalists were taken on a tour of sheep studs which included Canberra, central Queensland, Alice Springs and Broken Hill. The film concludes with the Wool Fashion Award of 1957.
